If above selection is 'No' then this must be 'Yes'

input.label: Effective Vaccine Management Initiative
input.hint: EVM Assessment Tool for health facility vaccine store

select1.label: District:
Block name:

input.label: If Other, Specify the block name

select1.label: L1 - Assessment Scope

input.label: Geo point
input.hint: Please ensure that co-ordinates are captured under clear sky.

upload.label: Image 1
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

upload.label: Image 2
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

input.label: L2.01 Supply Chain Levels - Service Point
L2.04 - Unique code for this facility:
L2.10 - Maximum temperature at site C
L2.11 - Minimum temperature at site C
L2.14 - Assessed records start date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L2.15 - Assessed records finish date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility
input.hint: In this section, record the specified details about the permanent employees of the facility.

group.label: L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility

input.label: Qualifications
input.hint: Specify level of education: e.g. technical college vocational qualification, university first degree etc.

input.label: Experience
input.hint: Record previous experience in the field of vaccine management. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

input.label: Years in post
input.hint: Record duration in the current post. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

group.label: E0 Complete these facility specific questions before continuing.

input.label: E0:01a What type of cold chain equipment is used in the store?
input.hint: Answers to this question switch later indicators on and off.

select1.label: A. Freezer room(s) and/or cold room(s) are used for storing vaccine?
B. Freezers and/or refrigerators are used for storing vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Including solar refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Freezer room(s), cold room(s), freezers or refrigerators are used for freezing icepacks or cooling cool water packs?
select1.hint: Select 'Yes' if there is equipment in the store used exclusively for freezing or cooling icepacks. Ignore fridge/freezers with icepack compartments or freezer rooms/cold rooms that are also used to store vaccine.

select1.label: D. Vaccine is not stored at this facility. Only cold boxes and/or vaccine carriers are used.
select1.hint: Some health facilities have no refrigerators and may use cold boxes or vaccine carriers to store vaccine for immunization sessions. In such cases, select 'Y' for option D and 'N' for all others.

input.label: E0:03a What type of equipment is used to deliver and/or collect vaccine at this store?

select1.label: A. Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and/or other passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Other passive containers' includes insulated roll containers or palletized containers. These may be used at primary and sub-national levels.

select1.label: B. Refrigerated vehicles?

group.label: E2 All vaccines & diluents are stored within WHO-recommended temperature ranges.

select1.label: E2:03a Can the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) give the correct storage temperature range for each of the vaccines on the schedule?
select1.hint: Knowledge of correct storage temperatures is vital. If the respondent gives any incorrect answers, score 'No'. Note also: 1) If s/he says that freeze-dried vaccines should be stored at -20C record this as 'Yes'. Current WHO advice is to store these vaccines at +2 to + 8C, but storage at -20C will not damage these vaccines. 2) If s/he say that freeze-dried vaccines packed with diluents can be stored at -20C, this answer MUST be scored as 'No'. 3) At service point level, it is correct to say that all vaccines can be stored at +2 to +8C

select1.label: E2:04a Do the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) know which vaccines on the schedule can be damaged by temperatures below 0C?
select1.hint: It is essential that respondents know which of the vaccines should not be exposed to temperatures below 0C. It is not important that they know the precise freezing temperature of each of these vaccines.

select1.label: E2:07a If there is refrigeration equipment, is there a complete set of manual temperature records for each and every cold room, freezer room, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer throughout the review period?
select1.hint: This question applies all in health facilities with active refrigeration. It does not apply in health facilities where cold boxes or vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine temporarily. Manual records are necessary because this is the only way to be sure that temperatures are checked at least twice a day. 'Complete' means that there should be no missing' record sheets or electronic temperature traces and that the entire review period should be covered for each appliance.

select1.label: E2:11a If there is refrigeration equipment, have temperature records been kept in a safe place for at least three years?
select1.hint: Countries should be encouraged to retain such records for tracing purposes. If records are not available for three years, review the records kept since the immunization programme adopted EVSM or EVM.

input.label: E2:12a If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature review checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : There must be a written record of these reviews which identifies problems and records actions taken. A verbal assurance is not sufficient.

select1.label: A. Are temperature records formally reviewed at least once a month in order to identify temperature excursions and their causes?
select1.hint: Check whether records are reviewed and recorded. 'Excursions' are temperatures below +2C or above +8C for cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators, and above -5C for freezer rooms and vaccine freezers.

select1.label: B. Have correct remedial actions been taken?
select1.hint: Interview the responsible person. Discuss and evaluate remedial actions taken.

group.label: E3 Cold storage, dry storage and transport capacity is sufficient to accommodate all vaccines and supplies needed for the programme.

input.label: E3:01a If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary level) or the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the +2C to + 8C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations.

input.label: A. Measure the net storage capacity of the +2C to + 8C store(s) in liters or m.
B. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The store capacity, taking account of utilization factor, is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum estimated volume of vaccine to be stored, +10%.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)

E3:09a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule or outreach session size data, establish whether coolant capacity is sufficient to meet maximum demand levels
input.hint: Collect site data, then use the sidebar tool to perform these calculations. There must be sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to produce an adequate flow of icepacks/chilled water.

select1.label: A. Is there sufficient freezing or cooling capacity to meet maximum demand? .
select1.hint: Icepack freezing or cooling may sometimes take place in another facility. If this is the case, the capacity of the other facility needs to be checked.

select1.label: B. Is there sufficient storage capacity for icepacks/chilled water packs storage to meet peak demand? .
select1.hint: Peak demand' is the maximum weight of icepacks/chilled water packs required in a day.

input.label: E3:10a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, establish whether there are sufficient passive containers to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Check total vaccine storage capacity of available passive containers and compare against delivery schedule. If containers are always supplied by the receiving store this question is not applicable here but must be assessed at the next level down in the supply chain.

select1.label: A. Does this store stock passive containers for delivery and/or collection?
select1.hint: Answer 'Y' if the store keeps a stock of passive containers. If delivery and collection dates are staggered, the same containers may be used for both purposes.

select1.label: B. Are there sufficient passive containers?
select1.hint: If some containers are in use, check the container inventory to establish how many there should be.

input.label: E3:11a If there is refrigeration equipment. Vaccine store contingency planning checklist:
input.hint: Contingency plans are context-specific, but should include the following minimum elements: 1) Identify the major sources of risk (e.g. power failure, flood, earthquake, etc.). 2) Prepare a written contingency plan. 3) Post emergency contact details on the noticeboard in the vaccine store. 4) Staff must know that the universal safe storage temperature for ALL vaccines in an emergency is +2C to +8C.

select1.label: A. Is there a satisfactory SOP which sets out a contingency plan in the event of equipment failure or other emergency?
select1.hint: 5) Identify at least two alternative cold storage locations. Inspect them to make sure they are large enough, well-managed, and can maintain correct temperatures.

select1.label: B. Are emergency contact details posted in the vaccine store?
select1.hint: 6) Ensure that there is a written agreement with the selected emergency providers. If payment will be required, make sure that this can be funded.

select1.label: C. Do staff know what to do in the event of an emergency?
select1.hint: 7) Regularly rehearse the contingency plan with store staff and the emergency providers.

group.label: E4 Buildings, cold chain equipment and transport systems enable the vaccine and consumables supply chain to function well

input.label: E4:03a Vaccine store or health facility building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Vaccine store' in this context includes service point health facilities.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine store building suitable for the climate?
select1.hint: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof free of leaks?
select1.hint: Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage?
D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)? .
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have they been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date. Fire extinguishers are unlikely to be found in small health facilities, so enter 'n/a'.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory?
select1.hint: Satisfactory' means that wiring, circuit breakers, electrical sockets and light fittings are in good condition and securely fixed in place. All circuits should be properly earthed. In a full inspection the earthing of sockets can be checked with a ring main tester. If there are any doubts, a professional inspection should be carried out. Service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)?
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
K. Is the heating system working?

input.label: E4:13a If there are refrigerators and/or freezers Vaccine freezer/refrigerator checklist.

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine freezers comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine freezers have continuous temperature recorders?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Continuous temperature recording in freezers is only mandatory at primary store level.

select1.label: C. Do vaccine freezers have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : All freezers should have a stem or dial thermometer.

select1.label: D. Do all vaccine refrigerators comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site. PIS and PQS pre-qualified equipment should have a sticker to show the climate rating.

select1.label: E. Are all ice-lined refrigerators fitted with the correct vaccine storage baskets?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : ILRs must always be fitted with baskets so that vaccine does not come into contact with the bottom or walls of the unit because this can freeze vaccine.

select1.label: F. Do all vaccine refrigerators have continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers or freeze indicators?
select1.hint: Continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers (Fridge Tag type) are essential at primary level. Refrigerator loggers are desirable at SN, LD and SP levels.

select1.label: G. Do all vaccine refrigerators have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
H. Where applicable, are there sufficient reserve supplies of kerosene and/or gas?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Sufficient' reserve supplies means at least one spare Jerry Can of kerosene or at least one spare full gas bottle.

select1.label: J. Where applicable, is kerosene or gas always available?
K. Cold climates only. Do vaccine refrigerators EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?

input.label: E4:14a If there is refrigeration equipment Inspect refrigeration equipment
A. How many refrigeration units are there (dual CR and FR units count as 2, refrigerators and freezers count as 1 each)?
B. How many of these are CFC-free?
E4:15a Standby generator.
input.hint: There should always be a standby generator at the primary store unless mains electricity is completely reliable and/or has a backup supply from a separate transformer. The same requirement applies at sub-national stores equipped with cold rooms. Generators are not required in small sub-national stores, lowest distribution level and service point stores where ice-lined refrigerators are used and there is at least 8 hours electricity per day. Generators are also not required where kerosene, gas or solar refrigerators are used or where a health facility uses cold boxes or vaccine carriers for storing vaccine.

select1.label: A. Is a generator required at this store?
B. Is a standby generator installed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If a generator is installed but is not required then the generator questions are switched off and need not be answered.

input.label: E4:16a If a generator is required and installed, standby generator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : The sidebar tool can be used to help with these calculations.

select1.label: A. Is the generator in working order?
B. Can the generator start all the connected equipment in the vaccine store? .
select1.hint: The starting load for a refrigeration compressor is much higher than the running load. Ask for a demonstration to prove that the generator is able to cope with the combined starting load of all connected refrigeration units. Well-designed systems may have 'smart switching' which reduces the starting load by automatically phasing in the individual refrigeration units.

select1.label: C. Is the fuel tank large enough?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 72 hours continuous running is recommended, but this is context-dependent. If power cuts are short and/or fuel is readily available, a smaller capacity will be acceptable. The way to assess this is as follows: 1) Establish the longest power cut experienced during the review period. 2) Check the generator fuel consumption in liters per hour. 3) Check the capacity of the fuel tank. If tank capacity/consumption per hour is less than the longest power cut then the tank capacity is too small.

select1.label: D. Are there sufficient reserve supplies of fuel?
E. Is the generator in a secure compound?
E4:17a Is the voltage fluctuation sufficiently severe to require voltage regulation equipment?
select1.hint: Voltage regulation equipment on all refrigeration equipment is essential if voltage fluctuations exceed 15%. Obtain information from an electrical engineer, or from the local supply company.

input.label: E4:18a If voltage regulation is required, voltage regulator checklist.
input.hint: If there is no refrigeration equipment in a particular category - e.g. 'freezer room', enter 0 for the equipment number and 0 for the voltage regulator number.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator?
input.hint: There may be a single central voltage regulator for the vaccine store or some sharing arrangement across multiple appliances. In this case score on the basis that every piece of equipment has a regulator and make a note in the comment box.

input.label: C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
E. How many vaccine freezers and refrigerators are there?
F. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
input.hint: Note: Solar refrigerators do not require voltage regulators. Absorption refrigerators require a different type of voltage regulator to those used for compression refrigerators. This needs to be checked during the inspection.

select1.label: E4:21a Are telecommunications links working?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Telecommunications links include telephone, internet and radio. At least one of these must be working well.

select1.label: A. If passive containers are used, do passive containers used at this level comply with WHO specifications?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Passive containers include cold boxes, vaccine carriers and palletiZed or roll containers. Identify products by using the PQS or PIS catalogue.

select1.label: B. If refrigerated vehicles are used, are the disposable cartons or reusable crates used to transport vaccine fit for purpose?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : No standard set. Use judgment to assess quality. Most important is the way in which cartons or crates are packed and restrained.

group.label: E5 Maintenance of buildings, cold chain equipment and vehicles is satisfactory.

input.label: E5:01a Planned preventive maintenance checklist for buildings.
input.hint: This question is primarily about planned preventive maintenance (PPM). However, it is possible that the building is in good condition because it is being informally maintained. 01 : C covers this option.

select1.label: A. Is there a written multi-year planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
select1.hint: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: If the score to question A is 'N' then the score for Question B must also be 'N'. PPM activities should be monitored and recorded.

select1.label: C. Is there visual evidence that maintenance is taking place?
select1.hint: If an effective maintenance programme is in place, the building should be in good condition. Indicators of poor building maintenance include broken light bulbs, leaks and damp stains, blocked drains, flaking paintwork, etc. See answers to E4:04a.

input.label: E5:02a If there is refrigeration equipment, Planned preventive maintenance checklist for refrigeration equipment.
input.hint: In this context, 'Planned Preventive Maintenance (PPM)' is as set out in the cold chain equipment manufacturers' service manuals. Both the need for and the timing of PPM can be foreseen.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : PPM should be recorded in a maintenance record book or worksheet.

select1.label: C. Is somebody assigned to carry out routine maintenance?
select1.hint: A permanent member of the facility staff must be formally assigned to carry out the tasks below. They should not be left to ancillary staff such as cleaners.

select1.label: D. Is there evidence that cold rooms/refrigerators/ freezers have recently been cleaned and defrosted?
select1.hint: Check for excessive ice accumulation on evaporator units or the inside lining. Ice accumulation or condensation along the panel joints in cold rooms and freezer rooms is a sign that panel joints are leaking or poorly designed.

select1.label: E. Is there evidence that kerosene refrigerator wicks have been trimmed and chimneys cleaned?
select1.hint: Frequent trimming and replacement of wicks in kerosene refrigerators is absolutely essential. Chimneys also need to be cleaned regularly, especially if kerosene quality is poor.

select1.label: F. Is there evidence that solar refrigerator battery electrolyte has been checked and solar panels cleaned?
select1.hint: Some flooded batteries are not sealed and require regular checking of electrolyte levels and topping up with battery acid. All solar panels should be cleaned from time to time to maintain efficiency. This is particularly important in dusty areas and in countries where there is snow.

select1.label: G. Are all solar panels completely unshaded by buildings, trees and overhead cables?
select1.hint: Shading seriously degrades solar panel performance. Shading problems can increase over the years following the original installation as trees grow, new buildings are built and new overhead cables are erected.

input.label: E5:05a If vaccine is stored at the facility AND there are refrigerators/freezers, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer maintenance checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Include all vaccine refrigerators and freezers in the store, unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many vaccine refrigerators and freezers are there (all types, including solar)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box. With kerosene units, check that the burner has been assembled correctly.

group.label: E6 Stock management systems and procedures are effective.

select1.label: E6:03a Are all vaccine arrivals and vaccine dispatches recorded and stock balances updated within one working day of the transaction?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : The practice of batch processing arrival and delivery slips should be discouraged because it leads to out of date stock records.

input.label: E6:04a Do the stock records record the following information for all vaccines.

select1.label: A. Type of vaccine
B. Vaccine presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Vaccine manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each vaccine batch
G. VVM status where applicable
H. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and at health facility level.

input.label: E6:05a Do the stock records record the following information for all diluents that are packed separately from the vaccine to which they belong.

select1.label: A. Type of diluent
B. Diluent presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Diluent manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each batch
G. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and in health facilities.

select1.label: E6:07a Are vaccine requisition forms used for ordering and receiving vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : See model SOP on requisitioning for guidance on good practice. Assess content of existing form(s) against the content of the model forms.

select1.label: E6:08a Is there an effective pre-delivery, or pre-collection, notification system in place?
select1.hint: Effective' means that the system is understood and used by the receiving stores and that deliveries or collections are reliably made on or near a day that has been arranged well in advance.

select1.label: E6:09a Do stock records and/or stock in hand demonstrate that vaccine is issued according to the 'earliest-expiry-first-out' (EEFO) principle?
select1.hint: Unless VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure, vaccines should always be issued in EEFO order. Health worker use of EEFO is covered by question E8:09. In PR, SN and LD stores, the stock records should contain the data needed to demonstrate compliance. Otherwise physically check the stock. In health facilities it may be easier to check the stock in hand.

select1.label: E6:10a Can the storekeeper make exceptions to the EEFO rule (e.g. because of VVM status)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure whilst early-dated stock is still at Stage 1, the heat-exposed later-dated stock should generally be issued first.

select1.label: E6:13a Does the issuing store have a completed arrival voucher for every delivery which took place during the review period?
select1.hint: Use judgment. If the review period has just ended, the arrival slip for recent deliveries may not yet have been received by the issuing store. There may be other legitimate reasons for missing forms. The important point is that the incoming goods must be checked and the form must be signed by the receiving store.

select1.label: E6:14a Does a representative sample of these completed arrival sections indicate that arrival checks were carried out correctly?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : As with temperature records, suspiciously 'correct' forms may conceal lax practices. If vaccines are put in quarantine for any reason, these vaccines should be ignored.

input.label: E6:15a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for management of damaged or expired stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the stock control system designed to record vaccine and diluent wastage due to expiry, freezing or heat-exposure?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If vaccine has to be discarded, any associated diluent must also be discarded. Failure to do this can lead to a stockpile of 'orphaned' diluent.

select1.label: B. If 'yes', do the records show that the system is being used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If the stock records show that there have been no losses during the review period, ask the storekeeper to confirm whether or not this is true.

select1.label: C. Do staff know that expired and damaged vaccine should be clearly labelled and stored out of the cold chain until final disposal?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Damaged vaccine must be clearly labelled and stored outside the cold chain to prevent it being issued in error.

select1.label: D. If 'yes', is there evidence that the procedure is followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check that there is no damaged/expired vaccine in the store.

input.label: E6:16a If there is a functioning system for recording damaged or expired vaccine, select a freeze-sensitive vaccine. Establish how many doses have been discarded during the review period due to freezing or exposure to high temperature.
input.hint: Carry out this check even if the storekeeper reports that no vaccine has been lost. A score of 5 is only achieved if the percentage of vaccine lost is no more than 1% of the doses issued during the review period. Exposure to freezing must have been confirmed by a shake test. Exposure to high temperature must have been confirmed by VVM colour changes.

select1.label: A. Select a sample vaccine

input.label: B. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine issued during the review period.
C. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine discarded because of incorrect storage temperatures.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This indicator can only be assessed if stock records are accurate, informative and truthful. If there is no method to record vaccine damage, the score is 0.

select1.label: E6:17a Are disposal facilities and procedures in accordance with WHO and/or national norms?
E6:18a Have records of discarded vaccine been kept for at least three years, or, if for a lesser period, since the immunization programme adopted the EVSM or EVM?
E6:19a Are internal reviews of the vaccine loss/damage records carried out at least twice a year?

input.label: E6:21a Check stockouts and related events during the review period.
input.hint: If no records are available, interview the storekeeper and make a judgment.

select1.label: A. Were vaccine stocks sufficient throughout the review period (no stockouts)?
select1.hint: A stockout occurs when the demand or requirement for an item cannot be fulfilled from the currently available inventory. It does not necessarily mean that there is zero stock. Cases may occur where there is a stockout, but this does not affect deliveries because a new vaccine arrival occurs before the next delivery has to be made. Question B covers this situation.

select1.label: B. Was the facility always able to supply all the lower level stores?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Deliveries to lower level stores are not applicable at health facility level.

input.label: E6:22a Physical inventory frequency checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

input.label: A. Enter the planned vaccine supply period, in months
B. Enter number of recorded physical counts of vaccine stocks carried out during the 12 month review period
input.hint: Primary stores should carry out a physical count at least 4 times a year. Lower level stores and health facilities should carry out a count at the time of each incoming delivery. The scoring logic assumes this frequency.

select1.label: E6:23a If vaccine is stored at the facility, choose a sample freeze-dried vaccine and diluent. Enter name.
select1.hint: This question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers. The following checks are carried out.

input.label: A. Carry out a physical count of the sample vaccine. Enter number of doses counted.
B. Carry out a physical count of the sample diluent. Enter number of doses counted.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : 1) If the diluent count differs from the vaccine count by >1% a 'Mismatch' message appears. Otherwise a 'Match' message appears.

input.label: C. Check stock records for sample vaccine. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : 2) If the vaccine stock records = the vaccine count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: D. Check stock records for sample diluent. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : 3) If the diluent stock records = the diluent count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: E. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly AND vaccine and diluent quantities are within 1% of one another (see results).
input.hint: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 0 and 4.

input.label: E6:24a If consumables are held in this store, choose a sample consumable.

select1.label: A. Choose a sample consumable. Enter name.

input.label: B. Carry out a physical count of the sample consumable. Enter number of items counted:
C. Check stock records for sample consumable. Enter number of items recorded as currently in stock:
D. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly. Use your judgment to adjust the score between 4 and 0 for mismatches.
input.hint: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem.

input.label: E6:25a If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for vaccine storage arrangements.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine stock secure?
B. Are contents labels fixed to all cold chain equipment indicating vaccine type, lot no. and expiry date?
select1.hint: Check for labels on the lid of feezers and refrigerators, or on the edge of the shelves in freezer rooms and cold rooms. Score 'n/a' where labelling is not needed. Labels are not required at health facility level unless there are several refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Are vaccines correctly stored?
select1.hint: No freeze-sensitive vaccines stored close to cold room evaporators, stored close to the ice lining in ILRs or stored close to the evaporator plate of service point refrigerators. No vaccines should be kept in the door shelves of domestic refrigerators.

select1.label: D. Is vaccine laid out in EEFO order, by type and by lot number?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Ask which vaccines of a particular type are going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: E. Is the vaccine store clean, dry and pest-free?

input.label: E6:26a If consumables are held in this store, checklist for dry storage arrangements.

select1.label: A. Are dry goods secure?
B. Are dry goods correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : 'Correct' means that stocks should be neatly stacked on pallets so that they are accessible and are not affected by floor washing.

select1.label: C. Are dry goods laid out in an orderly fashion and in EEFO order where applicable?
select1.hint: Syringes have expiry dates and must therefore be organized in EEFO order. Ask which stock is going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: D. Is the dry store clean, dry and pest-free?
E6:27a Are the records secure?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Records should be stored in lockable filing cabinets.

group.label: E7 - Distribution between each level in the supply chain is effective.

input.label: E7:06a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used, assess knowledge of coolant preparation and packing of cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers.
input.hint: Whether a systematic temperature monitoring, or journey profiling, study has been carried out. Coolant preparation includes icepack conditioning, preparation of cool water packs and preparation of coolant for palletized or wheeled passive containers.

select1.label: A. Icepack conditioning or cooling of chilled water packs is in accordance with WHO guidelines?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : For palletized or wheeled containers, follow the manufacturer's instructions.

select1.label: B. Is packing in accordance with appliance labelling or SOP?
select1.hint: Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers are designed to suit a particular size of icepack. Sometimes the correct size is not available. In such circumstances it is essential that store staff know what to do.

select1.label: E7:08a Cold climates only. Do staff know how to prevent vaccine freezing during transport?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Refer to SOP on freeze prevention for details.

input.label: E7:12a Assess vaccine losses caused by freezing or heat exposure during transport from the issuing store
input.hint: This is a difficult indicator to assess, unless the stock records are transparent and honest. 100% score is achieved if there are no losses. If losses occurred and damaged vaccine was replaced in a 'reasonable' time, the score is 50%.

select1.label: A. The EVM target is a total loss of less than 1%. (Score Y if this target was achieved, otherwise score N).
select1.hint: Reasonable period' depends upon the level in the cold chain and the established supply interval and the extent of the vaccine damage. The country should have a clear policy to cover this and the assessment should be made against this policy.

select1.label: B. If 1% loss target was exceeded. Was the damaged vaccine replaced within a reasonable period of notification to the issuing store?
select1.hint: If there is no fixed policy, use judgment. For example, at service point level, if the set supply interval is 4 weeks, then 2 weeks would be reasonable. If the supply interval is 2 weeks, then one week would be reasonable.

group.label: E8 - Appropriate vaccine management policies are adopted and implemented.

input.label: E8:01a Knowledge of the shake test
input.hint: Guidance Notes :This question is not applicable at health facility level in situations where there is no refrigerator

select1.label: A. Does the storekeeper or health worker know how to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: B. Does the storekeeper or health worker know when to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: C. Has the storekeeper of health worker carried out a shake test in the last 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Only score n/a if you are sure that there were no events in the review period that required a shake test.

select1.label: E8:02a Do health workers always use diluent and vaccine from the same manufacture and with matching presentations?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : This question addresses health worker behaviour only. Recording of diluent and vaccine lot numbers is covered and matching of diluent and vaccine quantities during storage is covered in E6.

select1.label: E8:03a Are diluents always kept in the cold chain before and during every immunization session?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : The assessor can only confirm this completely by observing an immunization session.

select1.label: E8:04a Are opened vials of freeze-dried vaccines discarded within six hours of reconstitution, or at the end of each immunization session?
E8:05a Are written instructions on the use of VVMs, such as posters and stickers, available to storekeepers and health workers?
E8:06a Do storekeepers/health workers know how to read VVMs?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Use dummy VVMs and/or sticker samples to check knowledge. To score 'Y', all those responsible in the facility must answer correctly.

select1.label: E8:07a Are the VVMs on all vaccines in the health facility refrigerator, cold box or vaccine carrier at VVM stage 1 or stage 2?
select1.hint: Vaccines at VVM stage 3 and stage 4 should not be stored in the refrigerator. The same applies where vaccine is stored in a cold box or vaccine carrier for an imunization session. Stage 3 or 4 vaccines might be found in cold boxes or vaccine carriers returned from a distant outreach session, but these vials must be discarded

select1.label: E8:08a Do health workers use VVM status for vaccine management purposes (e.g. do they use Stage 2 vaccines first)?
select1.hint: Check health worker knowledge using the following method. Sample 1: a stage 1 VVM on an early expiry date vial; Sample 2 a stage 2 VVM on a late expiry date vial. Ask which one should be used first. The correct answer is Sample 1.

select1.label: E8:09a Has the MDVP been adopted?
select1.hint: Verify this by inspecting written instructions. The correct implementation of MDVP is for the country to determine and some choose not to do so. Others may modify WHO guidance. For example, five days maximum after opening is a rule adopted by some. In this example, keeping for up to 5 days is correct; keeping for more than 5 days is incorrect, even though WHO guidance allows up to 28 days.

select1.label: E8:10a If MDVP has been adopted, Can health workers explain how to apply the MDVP?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : This question only applies if MDVP has been adopted.

select1.label: E8:11a If MDVP has been adopted, are opened vials of liquid vaccines correctly kept for subsequent immunization sessions?
select1.hint: Ask health workers to show which opened vials they will use for the next session and to verify this information through immunization records. Check that no opened vials have been kept for longer than the period stated in national policy, or 28 days if WHO guidance is followed.

input.label: E8:12a Review the periodic immunization reports and/or any other reporting forms that are used to monitor vaccine wastage. [Score 0 if there is no reporting. Score on a scale of 1-4 if formal reporting exists. Use commentary to elaborate].
input.hint: At national level this question should be adressed to the EPI Manager. At lower level stores wastage rates may not be calculated. However, the information needed for the calculation should be collected and reported up the supply chain. For example, number of children immunized, doses used and doses lost, destroyed or expired.

input.label: E8:13a Wastage calculation checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : At national level this question should be adressed to the EPI Manager.

select1.label: A. Do you calculate wastage rates for each vaccine?
B. Is there a standard form used to record wastage?
C. Is there a complete set of wastage records for the review period?
D. Are these data used to monitor vaccine management performance?
E8:14a Does the facility receive regular supportive supervision?
select1.hint: Ask staff when the last supervisory visit took place and how regular these visits are. Answer yes if the level of support is suitable, taking account of the general knowledge of the facility staff.

input.label: E8:15a Syringe disposal checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : These questions are not a substitute for a proper waste management assessment.

select1.label: A. Used syringes are immediately placed in safety boxes.
B. Syringes are de-fanged using a needle cutter and cut needles are kept safely for disposal
C. If safety boxes are used, Safety boxes are incinerated on site in a high temperature incinerator.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : High temperature' means between 650C and 1,200C. Burning in a pit on site is never acceptable.

select1.label: D. If safety boxes are used or syringes de-fanged, Safety boxes and/or cut needles are safely buried on site?
E. If safety boxes are used or syringes de-fanged, Safety boxes and/or cut needles are removed from site for safe disposal elsewhere?

input.label: E8:16a Vial disposal checklist:
input.hint: Answer 'Y' to only one option.

select1.label: Option 1: Used and discarded vials are safely buried on site?
Option 2: Used and discarded vials are removed from site for safe disposal elsewhere?
Option 3: Used and discarded vials are sterilised on site and safely disposed of?
